html: heweth him down cedars…he maketh a god, even his graven image. Isaiah points out the contradiction of creating and worshiping idols. The same tree a man uses for fuel to keep himself warm ("he warmeth himself, and saith, Aha, I am warm"; 44:16) and to cook meals ("baketh bread"; 44:15; "he roasteth roast"; 44:16) is used to make an idol—and the residue [of the tree] he maketh a god, even his graven image. The man takes a piece of the wood that was not used for fuel, and he takes his tools (ruler, marker, chisel, and compasses; 44:13) and carefully fashions a god. He then worships and prays to it, the work of his own hands, saying, "Save me, you are my god" (NIV 44:17).
